articles.headline: Gap Closing Chain Aimed at Over-30s
articles.snippet: Gap said that it would pull the plug on Forth & Towne, an 18-month-old chain for professional women that failed to catch on.
articles.abstract: Gap said that it would pull the plug on Forth & Towne, an 18-month-old chain for professional women that failed to catch on.
articles.lead_paragraph: So much for the forgotten 35-year-old woman.

articles.headline: Honeybees Vanish, Leaving Keepers in Peril
articles.snippet: Bees have been disappearing at an alarming rate in 24 states, threatening the production of numerous crops.
articles.abstract: Bees have been disappearing at an alarming rate in 24 states, threatening the production of numerous crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: VISALIA, Calif., Feb. 23 — David Bradshaw has endured countless stings during his life as a beekeeper, but he got the shock of his career when he opened his boxes last month and found half of his 100 million bees missing.

articles.headline: Iraqis Reach an Accord on Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: The move marked a major agreement among the country’s political blocs on a highly divisive issue.
articles.abstract: The move marked a major agreement among the country’s political blocs on a highly divisive issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 26 — The Iraqi cabinet approved a draft of a law on Monday that would set guidelines for nationwide distribution of oil revenues and foreign investment in the immense oil industry. The endorsement reflected a major agreement among the country’s ethnic and sectarian political blocs on one of Iraq’s most divisive issues.

articles.headline: Regulatory Clearance  Seen as Slow but Sure
articles.snippet: HOUSTON, Feb. 26 — The sale of the biggest utility in Texas to private investors faces months of state and federal regulatory hurdles, but experts predict that the broad support for the deal from environmentalists and other important interest grou...
articles.abstract: HOUSTON, Feb. 26 — The sale of the biggest utility in Texas to private investors faces months of state and federal regulatory hurdles, but experts predict that the broad support for the deal from environmentalists and other important interest groups should help it clear them with ease.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Feb. 26 — The sale of the biggest utility in Texas to private investors faces months of state and federal regulatory hurdles, but experts predict that the broad support for the deal from environmentalists and other important interest groups should help it clear them with ease.
articles.byline: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS  and MATTHEW R. WALD

articles.headline: Labor Shortage Pushes Mining Companies to Recruit and Pay More
articles.snippet: Prices for raw materials had languished for years, but the sector is now trying to meet global demand for iron, copper and other key commodities.
articles.abstract: Prices for raw materials had languished for years, but the sector is now trying to meet global demand for iron, copper and other key commodities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every time Sue Gogilis starts her shift driving the company truck she gives her steering wheel a good rub with a few disinfectant wipes.
articles.byline: By Wayne Arnold and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Song Wakens Injured Pride of Afrikaners
articles.snippet: The mere concept of Afrikaner pride remains an exquisitely sensitive issue among whites and blacks alike.
articles.abstract: The mere concept of Afrikaner pride remains an exquisitely sensitive issue among whites and blacks alike.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 26 — "Proudly South African" is this nation's E Pluribus Unum, a slogan stamped on products, echoed in radio commercials and inculcated into the new South African DNA. Much as America's motto celebrates melding many into one, South Africa's says that it doesn't matter what you look like — we can all be proud of our young country.

articles.headline: Court Declares Bosnia Killings Were Genocide
articles.snippet: The court cleared Serbia of intent to commit genocide, but said it had failed to prevent the Srebrenica massacre.
articles.abstract: The court cleared Serbia of intent to commit genocide, but said it had failed to prevent the Srebrenica massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE, Feb. 26 — The International Court of Justice on Monday for the first time called the massacre of Bosnian Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995 an act of genocide, but determined that Serbia itself was not guilty of the enormous crime.

articles.headline: Private Equity Buyout of TXU Is Enormous in Size and in Its Complexity
articles.snippet: A new tactic in financing is expanding the role of Wall Street banks, which have essentially served as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms.
articles.abstract: A new tactic in financing is expanding the role of Wall Street banks, which have essentially served as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks have provided billions of dollars to finance takeovers in the last year, essentially serving as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms, which are among the banks’ best-paying customers.

articles.headline: Citigroup Has a C.F.O. Now What?
articles.snippet: Citigroup is hoping that Gary L. Crittenden will bring the credibility and operational expertise needed to reverse the bank’s disappointing performance.
articles.abstract: Citigroup is hoping that Gary L. Crittenden will bring the credibility and operational expertise needed to reverse the bank’s disappointing performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: By hiring Gary L. Crittenden, Citigroup is hoping that a seasoned chief financial officer will bring the credibility and operational expertise needed to reverse the bank’s disappointing performance.
